a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:00): Any time a command can take a motion you simply hit the key for the command then a motion that would normally move the cursor and vim applies the command to the the area of the file that covers the current cursor position to where the motion would take the cursor.
eb9279982226a42afdf2860dbdc29b45 (10:00): Oh yes. Very much so.

a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:01): Some command keys can be "doubled" so the motion is the current line. So, for example, "dd" deletes the current line but you can do "dj" to delete the current and next line.
a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:01): Or "dG" deletes from the current line to the end of the file.
a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:03): == reindents the current line... So if you want to reindent the full file you need to type: gg=G

a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:03): It's very important to understand how to use commands that use a motion "argument".
a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:04): Commands that take a motion can also take what's called a "text-object" as their motion.
a14164e5871efd6f1f37bcee31bd943b (10:04): ...Which can often affect an area surrounding the cursor--both before and after its current position.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:05): :help ap , for instance
